p: Improvements in managing acute and chronic complications of sickle cell disease (SCD) have led to an increase in overall life expectancy for children living in high resource countries. [ 1] As a result, the prevalence of chronic end organ damage, such as stroke, pulmonary hypertension (PHTN), renal injury, avascular necrosis of bone and joints (AVN), and cutaneous ulceration, is likely to increase as most children with SCD are living into adulthood.
